turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in No. 02-809, Maryland v. Joseph Jermaine Pringle.
Mr. Bair.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
When the officer stopped the car respondent was riding in and found drugs packaged for distribution in the rear seat armrest, and then also found a large amount of cash in the glove compartment--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What... the rear seat armrest was pushed up--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and then the drugs were behind the... the armrest?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
The rear seat armrest was pushed up against the rear seat.
The officer merely folded it down and then the drugs appeared, and these are drugs that were packaged in five separate individual packages that were packaged for distribution at $20 a bag.

The officer also found $763 in a rolled-up ball of cash in the glove compartment, and there... at that time there was individualized probable cause that focused on all three people in that car, and this is so for three principal reasons.
First--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: At the end of the day, what happened?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --At the end of the day, all three were arrested, respondent confessed, and said the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And respondent was a front seat passenger?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Yes, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He's the one who confessed?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was found ultimately guilty of--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: He was found--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --some drug-related offense?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --He was found guilty both of possession and possession with intent to distribute.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the other two?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: The other two were not charged formally after respondent confessed.
The officer made a discretionary decision not to charge the other two at the station house after respondent confessed to this crime.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you say that there was probable cause for the arrest of all three at the time they were found?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was there probable cause sufficient to support charges at a preliminary hearing--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think there would have been.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --against all three?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I... yes, Justice O'Connor, I think there would have been.
I think, given the circumstances of this arrest, the mere fact that one of the three confessed doesn't ultimately determine that the other two were not culpable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there any additional requirement for establishing probable cause at a preliminary hearing above and beyond what's needed for the arrest, or are they identical, in your opinion?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I would say they're identical, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So... so under... under that view, assume no confession, hypothetical case, under that view, these people, all of the three could have been bound over for trial?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I believe so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And under that view, any motion to dismiss prior to trial would have to be denied?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I believe there would have been probable cause to charge and to take the cases to trial.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I suppose what happens in that case is the judge says, and I want to tell you right up front I think this is a very skimpy case, you'd better come up with something... I guess that's the way it works--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think so--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --But there's... but the... as Justice O'Connor said, it's probable cause and it's the same standard... excuse me... it's the same standard to bind over on arraignment as it is for the officer to arrest?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --My understanding from the case law, Your Honor, is that probable cause is probable cause, be it to search, to arrest, or it... I think it's a fluid concept, obviously depending on the exact context, and I'm not saying that a prosecutor would not exercise discretion as would a police officer in a given case not to take a case forward.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, a preliminary hearing is largely a matter of Maryland law, isn't it, or State law?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: It is and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, is there any... any constitutional requirement that there be a preliminary hearing before a criminal case is tried?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Not that I know of, Your Honor, no.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I take it even under the Constitution, if it's a Federal case, both the indictment and the... or the information shows simply probable cause, that's enough to bind over?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I believe so, Justice Kennedy, I believe so.
Now, in this case, of course, there was--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if you say it's fluid, that... that concerns me.

I was somewhat puzzled by what the Government said in its brief, page 26 to 28, it says, well, you know, it's fluid, the prosecutor takes a second look and it... it sounds as if the prosecutor has a greater burden, but I... I'm not sure that that's the law.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I'm not sure it's a greater burden.
I think the prosecutor's decision, of course, is looking forward to trial where they know that they have to prove the case beyond a reasonable doubt.
They know they have to get past a motion for judgment of acquittal.
The police officer on the scene is making the same type of decision vis-a-vis probable cause but it's in a very different context.
I think that's the difference.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In your view, is this very fact-specific so that it might come out differently if the money and the drugs had been located in some little pocket next to the driver as opposed to some rear seat passenger or other passenger?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think one factor that would significantly change the totality of the circumstances here would be, for instance, if the drugs had been found on the person of one of the passengers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, that wasn't my question.
What if--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: If it had been--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --they were found very close to the driver, you know, sometimes there's a little pocket right next to--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --In the door?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --on the door, on the driver's side.
Suppose it were there but you had a passenger in the front and in the rear.
Any different result?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Not in this case, no.
I think... I think if... if the drugs are found in a common area of the passenger compartment of the car--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about the trunk?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think the trunk changes things a little bit, but of course you have to look at the totality of the circumstances, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why a little bit?
I thought this whole case was predicated... your whole case was predicated on those drugs between the armrest and the backseat were accessible to all three people in that car.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, if you have something in a locked trunk, it truly is not accessible to the passengers.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --It certainly is not as accessible, and of course it's not as immediately accessible, but, for instance, if there had been a large quantity of drugs in the trunk or if there had been a dead body in the trunk, I think then there is a... the calculus changes in terms of totality of the circumstances, and I think if it were that situation, even though that particular evidence was in the trunk, I think there's still a... a strong inference that could be drawn that everyone in the car knew about it, because who would take the chance in terms of taking along innocent passengers--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, let's stick to the five... these five bags that were stuck in a Ziploc bag.
The Ziploc bag is in the trunk, not a dead body.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I understand.
I think in that case there would be a much closer case, it would be a much more difficult case vis-a-vis all three occupants of the car.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But under--
--Okay, what about the--

--under... under your view, if... if the car is in a high crime area and some mother gets a ride from her son who she perhaps doesn't know has been involved in drugs, then if drugs are found anywhere in that car, she's subject to arrest and... and sufficient for charge?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Not... not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, suppose it's at... in the middle of the day and she's going to the grocery store, we don't have it at 3:00 a.m. in an area where drugs are frequently sold.
Does that enter into the calculus?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think it does, Your Honor.

I think, obviously with... with... with the totality of the circumstances, anytime you change... and, of course, some of these are going to have more minor impact, some are going to have more major impact.
But in this case you had, of course, 3:16 in the morning, three men who were roughly of the same age who appeared to be intimately connected with one another, you had the drugs and the money.
I think here's a very strong case, but I agree, Justice O'Connor--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What if there had been four people in the car?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I don't know that four people would change things.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about six?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think within the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or what if it was a minivan and there were eight in the minivan?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I'm not sure it changes it significantly, Your Honor.
I think that the most significant--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You think with eight people in the minivan you could arrest all eight and hold them over for trial?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think if you have identical circumstances to these in terms of the time, how well-acquainted they all appeared, the fact there was money, the fact that there were drugs packaged for distribution.
It appeared to the officer, a reasonable inference, that there was a drug distribution common enterprise.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the distribution, as I understand it, was just enough to take care of a big party.
There was no evidence that they were for sale, was there?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Well, the evidence, at the time the officer made the arrest, I think he could draw an inference that there was cash proceeds perhaps of former drug sales, prior drug sales, and there were five individually packaged crack... hits of crack cocaine.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the charge was possession with intent to distribute, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Yes, it was both simple possession and possession with intent to distribute, and he was convicted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about if it had been a bus?
Now, we've gone from the sedan to the minivan, how about the bus?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think a bus is different, Your Honor.
I think a bus changes things significantly in the... in the context of, of course, the numbers of people are much greater, and then there's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you talking about a public bus or you're talking about a chartered bus?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think that would affect obviously the totality of circumstances as well.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What... what is... what is the rule that you're... there's the restatement hypotheticals... Restatement of Torts, where there's the dead body, two people are each accusing the other, and add... I don't know how the hypothetical would work... but add to the mix that only one could have done it.
Can you arrest both?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think you can, Your Honor.
I think both the Restatement of Torts, the Model Code of Pre-Arraignment Procedure, and just the... the nature of probable cause would permit that, because we're talking about--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The Model Code of Pre-Arraignment Procedure just talks again about probable cause?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Same situation where you have, say, two people, only one of whom could be guilty of the crime.
You could still have... you still would have probable cause to arrest both.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But that's two people and here you've got three.
What about three?
I was going to ask, what about three?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think three is... is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You can arrest all three?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about five?
You're going to arrest all five?
Even... I mean, you know, it gets worse and worse--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Well, of course.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --10 percent chance, there are 10 of them now--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: And... and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --so the chance that any individual one did it is 10 percent.
That's still enough?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think we can't draw... the Court in Gates said that you cannot quantify probable cause.
You have to... in those circumstances--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It doesn't mean probable.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --No, it does not mean probable.
Clearly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why do we call it probable cause?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I'm not... I think there's a bit of a misnomer there, but clearly from the case law of this Court, it means a fair probability, it means something greater than reasonable suspicion under Terry--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if you had to reduce it to a percentage figure, what would you call the percentage required for probable cause?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I don't know that I could, Your Honor.
I really don't know that it's useful to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it's less than 50, though, I gather?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Yes.
Your... the cases of this Court has said--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that takes care of the two people in the room, but when you get down to 33-1/3 with three people?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think... I think three people clearly would be--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And with four people it would be 25 percent.
Is that enough?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Probably, probably.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Probably.
[Laughter]
You... you agree... you agree that at some point the probability is... when the numbers of people present keep increasing, at some point the probability is going to be too slim?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Yes, I agree with that.

I agree with that, but again, in Illinois v. Gates, this Court said we will not, we cannot, it's not useful to try to quantify probable cause in that way, we still have to look at the totality of the circumstances beyond whether there are two people or three people or whatever.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And one is--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Of course, on the Government's theory I don't think it would matter, because they say you can infer a conspiracy, and I suppose then the whole bus could be in the conspiracy, but if it's an individual approach, which I think you're taking, then the number of people might make a difference.
I think so.
Now, of course, it would depend on... on the crime that the probable cause was going to.
In this particular crime, of course, drugs can be jointly and constructively possessed, so clearly in this particular car, all three of the people could be guilty of the crime, not just one.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Do you accept Justice Stevens' suggestion that your position might differ from the Government here?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I don't know that it does.
I think our positions are basically the same.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So... so you do think a conspiracy can generally... can be inferred as to all people in these... in the instance like this?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: In our case, absolutely, absolutely.
In our case, clearly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if one of them--
--But you didn't argue the... excuse me... you didn't argue the conspiracy theory in the State court, I don't think, did you?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Well, I think we did, Your Honor.
I think we argued in the State court that because drugs can be jointly and constructively possessed, that any one, two, or three of the individuals in the car were... were guilty of this crime.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If you know nothing more than what you know here... I mean, I take it that if... if it were undisputed that one of the three was a hitchhiker, you... you would not make the argument with respect to the hitchhiker?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think if... if it's undisputed, and of course, that's going to be a difficult situation to... to know that there's no actual connection--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's the wonderful thing about being on the Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --If it's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You can make those assumptions.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --If it's undisputed, then I think that significantly changes, because I think a lot... a core concept here is this notion of common enterprise, that when you have people in a car together, particularly a small passenger car, there's an inference, I think in this case a very strong inference, that all three of these people were engaged in a common enterprise.
So--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But do you have... do you need the--

--What if the car... what if the car included a driver and two hitchhikers and the drugs were found exactly as they were here, and there's obviously no common enterprise, would there be probable cause?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I guess it would be... of course, that would be a more difficult case because you had the money in the glove compartment of the car and the drugs in the backseat of the car, so that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm not sure the money really adds anything to the analysis, to tell you the truth.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think it adds--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because there's certainly nothing illegal about carrying money in the glove compartment, where it is illegal to carry drugs in the... behind the seat... the armrest.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Well, certainly the money without the drugs would be a... a different case than the drugs without the money.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you--
--The hitchhiker... the hitchhiker example poses a question for the arresting officer, because does he have to accept the declaration of someone that I'm just a hitchhiker here?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: No, and... and that, of course, goes back to whether it's undisputed in some way, I don't know quite how it would be undisputed.

You've always got the... the officer who on the scene is making a reasonable judgement from all the facts and circumstances, and one of those is, I don't have to believe the criminal or criminals in this car.
I know there are drugs in the car, we have a known crime here being committed in the presence of the officer, possession or possession with intent to distribute drugs.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I'm still curious about the answer to my question.

Assume the officer did accept the truth of the representation they were two... two hitchhikers picked up at different times, and maybe he was following the car, for instance, so he knew that was true, and then there's the driver and then there are drugs in the backseat just as there are here.
Would there be probable cause in that case?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Two... two answers to that, Justice Stevens.
One, of course, is you would measure the probable cause by an objective standard and not by the subjective standard of that particular police officer.
The other is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But what is the answer?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --The other is, it could be that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought you were going to say the two answers were yes and no.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --It could be, Your Honor, that the... the driver knew the hitchhikers and that's why he picked them up.
I mean, a lot of times people--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, no, no.

I'm just assuming the only relevant facts are that it's undisputed they were two... two unrelated... they're three unrelated people, they're just entirely different backgrounds, one doesn't even speak English and one doesn't speak Spanish, but there are three of them in the car and the drugs are found exactly under the circumstances here.
What I'm trying to say... if there were no conspiracy theory, would there be probable cause?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --I think so, yes.
Yes, I think there would be.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You... you have... you really have to say that based on the dead victim hypothetical that you answered earlier.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: I think so, I think so, that... that if the, again, one... the other inference among the... the... the indicators of a common enterprise would be, I think it's unusual that several people are going to be taking a chance driving around, either with evidence of a murder or evidence of a drug conspiracy.
They're not simply as a matter of reasonable inferences that an officer can draw, take the chance of having innocent people along.
Unless there are any further questions, I... I'd reserve the remainder of my time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Bair.
Mr. Srinivasan, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The totality of the circumstances apparent to the officer at the scene established probable cause for respondent's arrest.
Of particular significance, the officer uncovered drugs that were packaged for distribution and that were concealed in the location in which they were readily discoverable by the other passengers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your brief reads to me... at about page 15... to suggest that you're proposing a broad rule that probable cause exists to arrest all occupants of a car anytime commercial quantities of narcotics are found in the passenger portion of the car.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: It's... we don't intend--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that your position?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --We don't intend to suggest a broad rule, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you agree that it is a totality of the circumstances test?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: Yes, it's a totality of the circumstances test, and it will turn on contextual factors that are present in any particular case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you do say at page 15, beginning of the first full paragraph, for these reasons, the discovery of an amount of narcotics suitable for distribution in the passenger compartment supports an inference that all of the car's occupants were aware of, and hence, involved with the drugs.
That's a sweeping statement.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: Well, what... what we intend to say is that ordinarily when drugs that are packaged for distribution are found in a location in which they're readily discoverable by the other passengers, a reasonable officer can fairly conclude that there's a fair probability that each passenger is... is aware of the drugs, but of course in particular cases--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it... it might... wouldn't different factors enter into it?
Suppose it's a young child--

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --in the vehicle, and it's in the middle of the day and they're dropping the child off at school or something.
Are you suggesting there would nonetheless be this inference and the child could be hauled up and sent to the juvenile court?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: No.
The inference is tethered to the particular facts of this case.

In cases that present different facts, for example, if a child was in the car of... if, as was earlier discussed, a hitchhiker were in the car, the probable... probable cause calculus would be different.
But in this case there was no reason to suspect that any of the individuals was uninvolved in the possession of the cocaine.

In fact, what's particularly significant in this case in our view is the location in which the drugs were found, because they were found wedged behind the rear seat armrest, which apparently is the type of armrest that's adjustable in an up or down position.
The very purpose of that type of armrest is to give the passenger an option according to his preference whether the position... the armrest in one position or the other, so it's highly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The only evidence that supports the notion that some were uninvolved is that as soon as one of them confessed, the police immediately dismissed the charge against the other two, and therefore abandoned the notion that it was a common enterprise.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Well, I... it... there's a... I think there's a different question concerning whether there was probable cause for an arrest and the determination by an officer whether to proceed with charges.
Just because the officer--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You'd think if the... if the backseat person or whoever it was that confessed had confessed while the officer was arresting him, there would have remained the probable cause as to the other two?
Could he have said, I don't believe you, I'll take all three of you in anyway?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --There might well have been, Justice Stevens, because an officer's not required to believe the version of events that's given to him by people on the scene.

It might well be the case that they have a coordinated plan in advance to pin the blame on a particular person as opposed to the other two, and an officer can take into account the totality of circumstances in making that type of assessment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I... may I clarify whether you are indeed relying on common enterprise?
I thought the view was it may or may not be a common enterprise, but here is a situation, drugs equally accessible, drugs accessible to any one of the three.

We can't say whether all three or which one, so looking at the three, and we say, well, it's not more... not more likely the driver than the front seat passenger, who's there behind the money, or the backseat passenger, because any one of them could have pulled down that armrest.
I thought that was your theory, not a... not necessarily a common enterprise.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Ginsburg.
It's not necessarily a common enterprise.

It could be any one of the three or it could be all of them or some combination of the three of them, and the combination of those various scenarios rose to the level of a fair probability that respondent was involved with the cocaine.

And as I was... as I was saying, that's particularly the case because they were concealed behind the armrest, which is a type of instrument that affirmatively invites manipulation by a passenger, so if one of the occupants of the vehicle alone were responsible for carrying cocaine, it seems quite unlikely that he would have chosen the area behind the armrest as a place to conceal it from the other passengers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do... do we demand the same standard from the arresting officer as we do from the district attorney who decides whether or not to proceed to preliminary hearing?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: The probable cause standard works the same.
In both situations the question would be whether there's a fair probability.
Now--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But... but do we demand a higher standard--

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Well, it's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --from either of them in making that assessment?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --It's often the case that prosecutors will have more rigorous standards as a matter of internal... matter of internal guidelines.
And for example, in the U.S. Attorney's manual, it dictates that prosecutors in the Federal system need to ensure that it's likely that they'll be able to obtain a conviction on--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well isn't... isn't that... that means the... the probable cause standard is the same, but the prosecutor has an obligation to try to find out more and get more evidence before he goes forward.
Isn't that the difference?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Right.

The nature of the application of the probable cause standard is different in the prosecutorial stage because the prosecutor is identifying a particular offense, laying out the facts to support that offense, and the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the... but the standard... the standard that determines the... the... the degree of likelihood of inference, that is the same standard, whether we're talking about the police officer or whether we're talking about the district attorney later?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Correct.
That remains constant in both scenarios.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I... I'm not sure what you're saying.
You're saying it... it can get to the jury with no more than probable cause and should not be thrown out by the court?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: There's a different... there's a different question whether the evidence is sufficient to convict as presented by the prosecutor and whether the prosecutor has enough to go forward with the charges.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but you're saying the prosecutor does not have an obligation to refrain from bringing a prosecution where he plainly on the face of it doesn't have enough evidence to convict?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: As long as there's probable cause to go forward, the prosecutor can go forward with the charges.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To say plainly on the face of it is something that a... a prosecutor is seldom confronted with.
I mean, you've got different people telling different stories usually and it's usually a question of who's believed.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: That's correct, Mr. Chief Justice, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I'm assuming he has three people in the car and the chance for each of them is 33-1/3 percent--

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Well, he could go--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and he prosecutes one of them and he has nothing else.
That's all he has, three people in the car, stuff in the back seat--

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Well, that's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and he picks the passenger and brings a prosecution.
The passenger, it could have been me, it could have been the other two, 33-1/3 percent.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --Well, that's... that's different from the facts of this case, but even assuming that it were an equal likelihood that each of them independently were involved in the offense, the prosecutor could go forward in that situation, but it's highly unlikely that he would go forward in that situation because... because he's unlikely to obtain to a verdict in his favor.
So there's institutional incentives--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the district court probably would not let the case go to the jury if the motion was made at the end of the prosecution's case and this was all you had?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --That's correct, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The prosecution should... the prosecutor should bring cases which clearly will not be able to go to the jury?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: No, not should bring cases--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May, may.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --May, under the Constitution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay, that's not my understanding of the prosecutor's--

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: And that's why, I think, prosecutors typically enforce upon themselves a more rigorous obligation than the probable cause standard.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --But we have no case saying that they may not proceed?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: No, there's no case that I'm aware of that says that they can't proceed where there's probable cause.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you just said the manual instructed them not to bring cases to trial.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: In... in the Federal system--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --there's Federal guidelines that spell out when Federal prosecutors are supposed to bring cases to trial, but I'm not aware that that's required by Federal law or by the Constitution.
Each prosecutor's office might have their own--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you have readily at hand the... the citation to the manual?

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: --I don't... I don't have the particular provision.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, the... the manual wouldn't in any way bind Maryland authority.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: That's correct.
Each prosecutor's office might have different standards.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If... if the Federal manual binds anyone.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: Right.

Well, the deficiencies in the Maryland court's probable cause analysis, we think, are particularly are apparent when one considers the implications for officers at the scene in circumstances like this case, because apparently the up-shot is that officers either could arrest no one or that they could arrest the driver alone, and the latter situation seems unsound because perhaps the least likely scenario in circumstances like this case is that... that the driver was acting alone and carrying the contraband in the car, because if the driver in fact were acting alone, one might expect that he would conceal the contraband in a location in which it was not so readily discoverable by the other passengers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about the respondent's position that your position means two innocent people may be locked up in jail, because suppose Pringle hadn't fessed up, and he exercised his right to remain silent.
Then you might have a prolonged periods, assuming they couldn't make bail, three people stuck in the brig and two of them are innocent.

turn.speaker: sri_srinivasan
turn.label: Mr. Sri Srinivasan
turn.text: Yes, Justice Ginsburg, it's possible that innocent persons will be arrested and bound over in circumstances like in this case, but the probable cause standard accepts that possibility as the cost of ensuring the effective enforcement of the criminal laws.
In fact, this Court reiterated in Wardlow recently that the probable cause standard accepts that innocent persons may be arrested on occasion.
That's simply the cost of a functioning criminal justice system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Srinivasan.
Ms. Forster, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

This is a unique case with highly unusual facts, and the reason it is unique is because of the facts... not because of the facts that exist so much in this case, but because of those that do not exist here.
There was no testimony whatsoever in this case that Mr. Pringle had control over or knowledge of the drugs hidden in the back seat of the car--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ms. Forster, when you say testimony, you're not referring to any scheduled hearing or formal hearing, are you?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, what the court in Maryland reviews on appeal is the motion to suppress hearing, and at that hearing there was no evidence presented whatsoever that the officer in this case noticed any furtive movements by Mr. Pringle, any furtive gestures, that he said anything suspicious at the scene, or that he acted in any unusually nervous manner.
All we have here--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I thought we were considering this on the basis offered, which is the three people at 3:30 a.m. in a high crime neighborhood in a sedan where there were a certain quantity of drugs behind the armrest and money in the glove compartment.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --A few corrections, if I may, Justice O'Connor--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Three people in the car.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --This is... 3:00 a.m. is accurate, 3:16 a.m. It is in a residential area.
This was not in fact a high crime area.

And I think that under the totality of circumstances we have to put that in context, and the context is this, that it's 3:00 a.m. on a Saturday night with a car of three young men in their twenties in a residential area, and I think that anyone who has children of that age knows that often their Saturday night does not even begin until 10:00 or 11:00 p.m.--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, a lot of people wouldn't refer to children as being in their twenties, I think.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Young adult children, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You... you make an interesting opening statement that this is a highly unusual... we've... a lot of us read a lot of these cases.
It seems to me this happens all the time, that drugs in the car, the person says, it's not mine.
It seems to me that that's commonplace.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: But what we have here with respect to Mr. Pringle is simply presence and nothing more.
We have no further--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But isn't there... isn't there something more than presence here?
Isn't the significance... isn't the significant evidence of this case something that appears when you contrast it with Houghton from a couple of years ago?
Houghton, you had evidence that the driver of the car was a recreational, a personal drug user.

We don't, I think, in this society, at least certainly today, assume that everyone who is in the company of a recreational drug user is also a drug user or an accessory to the first person's drug use.

Here, however, what the police officer had was evidence, not merely of the time, but of... of three people in a relatively small car with commercial quantities of drugs, an amount of money that was enough to suggest that drug dealing was going on, and I think a... an inference was possible that someone in that car was dealing in the drugs.

And it seems to me that the different inference that can be drawn about the others here as distinct from the inference in the Houghton case is, most drug dealers do not go around in their place of business, the car, with people who are totally innocent of drug activity--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --If I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and isn't that the basic difference between this and Houghton and doesn't that inference support... amount to probably cause?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Your Honor, if I... if I may, with respect to this being packaging... the drugs packaged that is indicative of sale or for distribution, there was absolutely no evidence in this record that this was anything inconsistent with personal use.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Five... five crack cocaine hits?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
In fact, I think that there are a lot of crack cocaine addicts for which that is a small amount of personal use.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But is--
--How about a big roll of money?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: And, Your Honor, also, there's a problem with the record in this respect with regard to money--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you pointed it out, but I think it... I thought, and tell me if I'm wrong here, I thought that it was... it was... the evidence was, regardless of how he first described the quantity that he saw, I thought the evidence came out that there was 700 and some odd dollars in it, so I think the judge could infer that it was fairly... a fairly sizable roll of bills.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Justice Souter, the actual amount did not come out until the trial.

That never came out at the motion to suppress hearing, and in fact, the amount of money was never characterized at the motion to suppress hearing by the officer who testified, other than to say he saw the sum of money, that's all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And what is in... and it was in the glove compartment?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: It was concealed in the glove compartment?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And it was open, it wasn't in a wallet or something like that?
A roll of bills.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: We don't... we don't know.

In fact, the officer who... Officer Snyder, when he testified at the motion to suppress hearing, simply said that when Mr. Parlo, the driver of the automobile, went to retrieve his license and registration from the glove box, that is when I saw the money.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So it's reasonable--
--But he... he must have seen it in the form of a... a roll of bills or something, rather than, as Justice Souter said, just not in a wallet.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: The record is unclear.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but, I mean, you... you don't have to have been born yesterday to decide that.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Well, the... Your Honor, I guess the point is, is that all that was before the trial... the trial judge at the motion to suppress hearing... there was never any characterization of the denomination, the amount, nothing, just the only thing that was said was the money.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you have a roll of bills exposed in your glove compartment?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: At times I do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You do?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You better be careful if you do.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: I might also point out that at the actual trial, the expert who did testify for the State with regard to the... whether or not this was an intent to distribute... testified that without Mr. Pringle's confession and this statement, he could not in fact say that this was consistent with an intent to distribute based solely--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So it was at least possession.
So would you concede that a crime... in the officer's presence there was evidence of the commission of a crime?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then... so the officer says, I know that a crime has been committed.
In the whole world there are only three possible people who could do it.
What instruction would you give to the officer on the scene who knows that a crime has been committed, there are three possible people, but he can't say which?
Is it the answer that he can make no arrest?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: No, that's not the answer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What arrest can he make?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, in this case, the officer could arrest Mr. Parlo, the driver of the automobile, because I think it is universally accepted that we can impute the driver owner of an automobile with the knowledge that he knows what is in his car and he has exclusive control over that which is in his car.
So the officer here should have arrested Mr. Parlo.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And no one else?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Your Honor, I would suggest that perhaps... I mean, and of course, this is not the issue before the Court, that perhaps because of Mr. Smith, the backseat occupant, may also have been arrested given that the nature of an armrest is not really a normal repository that one would place personal items in--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So maybe... definitely the driver, maybe the backseat passenger--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Maybe Mr. Smith.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --but not the one who in fact--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: But definitely--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --who in fact committed the crime.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Definitely not Mr. Pringle, but of course, if we're going to use Mr. Pringle's confession in determining in hindsight, we need not have--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If this were... if this were a bus or a tavern or a theater or some of the examples, then it certainly would unreasonable to assume that the front seat passenger could reach back to the last row of the theater.
But here, this was a small car.
It isn't hard for somebody in the front seat to turn around and push down the armrest.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Justice Ginsburg, I agree with that... that perhaps it would not be difficult, given the compact nature of this car.
However, there was no testimony that in fact that anyone saw Mr. Pringle do that, number one, and number two--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that's because they... they didn't have a buy committed in the presence of the officer at the scene.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Well, I... I understand that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, I don't know why that counts against--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Well, my second response would be this, that I think that it would be highly unreasonable that Mr. Smith, the backseat passenger, would allow Mr. Pringle to turn around and store the drugs in the armrest right next to him.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Why?
Ms. Forster, the Maryland Court of Appeals, which ruled in your favor, says, during the search Officer Snyder seized $763 from the glove compartment, so they are... they accepted that as a fact.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Your Honor, the Maryland... with all due respect, the Maryland Court of Appeals made a mistake in this case because what they said in their opinion--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but no, we take the facts as the lower court found them.
I mean, I don't think it will do to say that the court of appeals is wrong on the facts.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Your Honor, what the court of appeals incorrectly did in this case was... and they dropped a footnote to suggest that it was unclear to them whether or not there was a separate motion to suppress hearing or whether there was a combined motion to suppress trial proceeding.
In fact, that's incorrect.
There was a separate motion to suppress hearing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the... but they nonetheless say that Officer Snyder seized $763.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: That's true, Your Honor, and for purposes of Mr. Pringle's position, the fact that that money is concealed, really it makes no difference the amount.
However, if the... as the petitioner and the U.S. Solicitor find the amount to be significant, I think we should have a clearer record.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why... why did you say the driver, I mean, on your theory?
I think it would be harder for the driver who's driving along to put the bags back in the backseat than it would be for the passengers.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Well, Justice Breyer, that assumes that the driver did not put it there before he picked up his passengers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if he put it there before, wouldn't they all know it was there?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.
If it's... if it's sandwiched between the armrest as it's pushed up against the seat, no, I don't.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the driver consented to have the car searched, so one might think, my goodness, if he knew there were drugs there, why did he say yes when he could have said no?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I can tell you as a criminal defense lawyer that defendants consent all the time when they have a car full of drugs and they know the drugs are there.
It's not unusual and it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This is not like the... one of the cases that you relied on is the Di Re case.
Your answer to me was, arrest the driver.
There, the informer had fingered the driver, so the police knew that they had the right man when they arrested the driver.
Here, it isn't at all like Di Re because the driver may or may not have been the right person.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Except that... how this case is similar to Di Re is that in Di Re this Court held that if the act... the criminal activity, the ongoing criminal activity, is not visible to the occupants, the mere presence is not enough on which to have probable cause to arrest.
And here we have concealed drugs and nothing more than Mr. Pringle's presence in the front seat.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there... there's... there's another difference.
The drugs are not locked up in the trunk.
They are at a place where the backseat person could push it down.
There wasn't a serious attempt to hide those drugs securely.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Yes, Justice Ginsburg, I agree with that.
But however, that would only point more closely to Mr. Smith, the backseat person sitting directly next to the armrest, not to Mr. Pringle, the front seat passenger.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, except if... if you accept the proposition that the... that there probably was a roll of bills visible in the glove compartment, Mr. Pringle was within easy reach, not even arm's reach of the rolled bills.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Well, Justice Souter, the... the problem with that, of course, it's pure speculation, but we don't even know if this glove compartment was locked or unlocked.
What we know is that it was opened by the driver at the time he was asked to retrieve his license and registration.
Whether he had to unlock that glove compartment is not clear at all for the record.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, we... we don't know that and we don't know whether the armrest had come down during the time the backseat passenger was there.

There are lots of things at a probable cause stage that one does not know, but the very fact... if... if we're going to talk... if we're going to find it significant that something is within reach of one of the passengers or not, I would have supposed that for probable cause purposes, the fact that the money was in reach was a relevant fact.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: But, Your Honor, I... I think that if we want to speculate that perhaps then we could say that that would be enough, but probable cause requires far more than speculation.

It requires a fair probability, at least of complicity, and we simply don't have the facts in this case that would support that fair probability with respect to Mr. Pringle, because all the record shows is that Mr. Pringle was present in a car where drugs were found hidden.

And if I may address the common enterprise theory that both the petitioner and the U.S. Solicitor relies on in this case, the problem with the common enterprise theory is that the cases that they cite in support of that involved ongoing criminal activity that was conducted in plain view.
You have the Ulster County case, where the Court found that the weapons, one of which was described as as large as a cannon, that was in plain view of all of the occupants of the car.
And in the Houghton case... so it was reasonable in the Ulster County case, or if that had in fact been the issue in that case, which it was not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Those I just think that... look, it just doesn't strike me as plausible that when you have three people in a car, one of them would stuff some drugs behind an armrest where they're very easy to find, unless he thought the other two were in on it, I mean, unless you thought the other two at least didn't care, and if they didn't care they're out there transporting the drugs with them.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So... so how... I don't even know, I mean, what I'm struggling for is, that seems like a reasonable inference so how... how do I know, I mean, I'm making this kind of inference.
How do I know whether I should or not?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Justice Breyer, the inference that the backseat passenger may stuff the drugs in the armrest--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Any of the three, I mean, any of them might, and why would they?
Why... you'd have to be crazy to be stuffing crack into a car like that without thinking your friends are... have... don't give a damn at the very least--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --But certainly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and probably are in on it.

But certainly, I think that even if they... he does that in the view of Mr. Pringle, that... so that Mr. Pringle has knowledge that the drugs were shoved in the armrest... that certainly does not also go to the next level, which is that Mr. Pringle possesses those drugs.
I may see one... a passenger--
--Would... would... would the... the officer at that point then be able to say, ah, but, in any case I could arrest the other two because they're harboring a felon?
In other words, you said that you could maybe arrest the ones who sitting next to the... the other, since the drugs are barely concealed?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Well, no, Your Honor, I... perhaps I... I was not clear.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Here's what she's thinking, and there might be a million different crimes.
You say to the front seat passenger, everything's the same, but you say to the front seat passenger, Mr. Front Seat Passenger, did you know that there were drugs down there in the armrest?
And he says yes, and that's all he says.
I would imagine he could be arrested then, couldn't he?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You couldn't arrest him then?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --I don't think he could be arrested.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For transporting the drugs or helping to transport them or being an accessory or doing something?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Well, certainly if he's the front seat passenger and not the driver he's... he's along for the ride.
He's not necessarily the person transporting--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, he doesn't say anything.
We don't know anything about it.
He just says, sure I knew there were drugs back there, that's all.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Under those circumstances, Your Honor, I think you'd have a much closer case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, no, but... but no, look, either there is a crime of being in a car knowing that or there isn't.
Is there or not?
I don't know.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Well, the crime of possession requires not just knowledge, but it also requires the intent to exercise dominion and control over the drug.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right, so... so you'd have to then make an inference that a person who says, yes, I knew the drugs where there, was also going to help later on.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Yes.
That would--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
But that's--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --there would have to be some reasonable inference--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --And you think that's not reasonable either?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --I think it is not just on those facts alone.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.
Am I right in assuming that the other two people in the car didn't testify at the suppression hearing?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: No, they did not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or at the trial?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: No, Your Honor, nor at the trial.
Only Officer Snyder testified at the motion to suppress hearing for the State.

If I may go back to the common enterprise theory, as I said, the cases that the State and the U.S. Solicitor rely on here involved criminal activity conducted in plain view, and... which, from which an officer could reasonably infer, I think, a common nefarious enterprise.

We have a... less than one gram of cocaine in this case that is hidden, hidden, concealed in the backseat armrest, and secondly, again, with respect to this being a commercial quantity of drugs, there is simply nothing in the record that supports that.
This was--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it was in separate little packets, right?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Yes, it was, but that, again--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: A kind that people would buy for a single dose?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --That, again, your Honor, is not inconsistent with personal use, and certainly I should think that if this police--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah, and one of their charges was possession, was it not?
I mean, we're not dealing only with intent to distribute but--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --That... that is correct.
The charge was possession--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Pure possession is what--

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --and possession with intent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, to say it's not inconsistent with personal use, I don't think gets your client totally off the hook, because something can be both consistent with personal use and consistent with commercial intent.
You know, something can... you can infer both ways.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: However, Justice Rehnquist, here this amount is not indicative of an operation that requires the participation of more than one person.
This is an amount that, if it's for sale, it's for sale--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But... but how about the combination of that with the... with the $763 roll in the glove compartment?

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, I think then it would still require speculation on the part of this police officer to assume that one was connected to the other.

I think that the only common enterprise that reasonably could have been inferred from the facts of this case is a common enterprise to go from one destination to another and nothing more than that, and given the concealed nature of the drugs in this case, the lack of any suspicious activities on Mr. Pringle's part, and the lack of, I think, any reasonable inference pointing to complicity that he possessed the hidden drugs, the Maryland Court of Appeals in this case correctly held that there was no probable cause to arrest Mr. Pringle, and this ruling should be affirmed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Forster.

turn.speaker: nancy_s_forster
turn.label: Ms. Nancy S. Forster
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bair, you have 4 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
I just wanted to first clarify any record inconsistencies or... or clarifications that might be in order.

I believe that the court of appeals' opinion, which is at appendix page 3A to the petition for cert, makes very clear that the court of appeals, the highest court in Maryland, construed the record as the officer seeing a large amount of money rolled up in the glove compartment, and it totaled $763.
That is clearly stated in the court of appeals' opinion, and I would direct the Court's attention to the trial transcripts at pages 83 to 84.
It is not in the joint appendix but it is in the record in the case, the trial transcript pages 83 to 84 from the trial on April 10th of 2000.

The police officer who arrested respondent testified at the trial that he saw a large roll of money in the glove compartment and that it totaled $763, so clearly there is record support and the court of appeals so found.
With regard to the glove compartment being closed or locked, there's nothing in the record ever indicating that the glove compartment was locked.
I think the only natural inference from this record is that it was closed at the time the car was stopped.

The officer saw the drug... excuse me... saw the money in the glove compartment when the driver went to retrieve his vehicle registration, and then after the officer obtained consent to search the car, he then opened the glove compartment again and seized the money.
I think it's ironic that the rule that is being suggested by respondent is the bright line rule that the driver should always be arrested.
I think that's absolutely inconsistent with this Court's Fourth Amendment law.
In closing, unless the Court has any questions--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah, I do have one--

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --which is, I think she said, look, there are three possible inferences.
One is that the passenger had nothing to do with it, didn't know about it.
Two is, everybody knew about it but that's all.
And three, they knew about it and wanted to help sell the drugs.
All right.
Now, she says, one plus two are so great that three isn't probable cause, but about, at least two.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: Your Honor, I think all... the nature of probable cause is that the officer is entitled to accept under the totality of the facts any of those inferences.
I think any... any--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Two... two isn't a crime, I mean, if they just all knew about it?

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Under Maryland law, they have to have an intent to exercise control over the drugs.
If they simply knew about it, that would not be enough for a conviction, but I think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It has to be all three... it has to be three is great enough, so despite one plus two... okay.

turn.speaker: gary_e_bair
turn.label: Mr. Gary E. Bair
turn.text: --Yes, but I think for probable cause purposes, clearly that would be sufficient.
Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Bair.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
